title: Bound by Law? Tales from the Public Domain
text:
Bound by Law?: Tales from the Public Domain is a comic book about <a href="intellectual%20property%20law">intellectual property law</a> and the <a href="public%20domain">public domain</a> published in 2008 by <a href="Duke%20University%20Press">Duke University Press</a>. Written by <a href="Keith%20Aoki">Keith Aoki</a>, <a href="James%20Boyle%20%28academic%29">James Boyle</a> and <a href="Jennifer%20Jenkins%20%28IP%20lawyer%29">Jennifer Jenkins</a> and supported by the <a href="Center%20for%20the%20Study%20of%20the%20Public%20Domain">Center for the Study of the Public Domain</a> at the <a href="Duke%20Law%20School">Duke Law School</a>, the book was first released in a free digital edition under a <a href="Creative%20Commons">Creative Commons</a> license in 2006. The 2008 edition has an introduction by <a href="Cory%20Doctorow">Cory Doctorow</a> and a foreword by <a href="Davis%20Guggenheim">Davis Guggenheim</a>.
The comic was widely reviewed, as an editor's pick by ' and by the "<a href="Michigan%20Law%20Review">Michigan Law Review</a>" among others.
The comic follows a fictional filmmaker named Akiko who struggles with the practicalities of applying the <a href="fair%20use">fair use</a> doctrine while making a documentary film. The book is "illustrated with a mix of hand-drawn artwork and collages of pop culture images".
The book has also been used as a resource for educators, recommended by the <a href="National%20Writing%20Project">National Writing Project</a> and used by workshops at the <a href="Ohio%20State%20University">Ohio State University</a>.
